column1: The written history of Douarnenez begins around 1118 when
column2: according to a charter dated 1126

column7: the island became known as Tristan.The hamlet which grew up at today's Port of Rosmeur was originally part of the parish of Ploaré. It did not become a commune in its own right until 1790. In 1945
column8: Douarnenez was expanded to include Ploaré

column1: Douarnenez owes much of its prosperity and expansion to the construction of railways at the end of the 19th century
column2: which provided services for passengers and goods
column3: connecting the port to other markets.  from the end of the nineteenth century. From the railway station at the centre of Tréboul
column4: the SNCF operated a service to Quimper. The route began operations in 1884. In the mid-20th century
column5: many former passengers had shifted to privately owned vehicles and passenger trains were discontinued in 1972. Goods traffic and shipping by rail continued until the railway was closed in 1988. The old line has been converted into an 18 km (11 mi) cycling and walking track
column6: providing an excellent means of discovering the surrounding countryside.

column1: The so-called Youtar was a small-gauge railway out of Dounarnenez to Audierne via Pont-Croix. Inaugurated in 1894
column2: it was shut down in 1936 during the Great Depression. It was reopened during the Second World War and was finally closed after the war in 1946. The old track between Audierne and Pont-Croix has been converted into a footpath along the River Goyen.

column1: The Breton people migrated to this area from south-west Britain in the 4th to 6th centuries
column2: bringing their language and culture. Breton
column3: a Brythonic language
column4: bears great similarities to the Cornish and to Welsh languages of southwest England and Wales. Many of the traditional stories and myths also share a Breton-Cornish heritage. In the early 21st century
